Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 53148-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
August 2019 
 
 
 
 
Sustainable Tourism Development in the Central Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation Region 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  Shixin Chen, Operations 1 
Director General  Werner E. Liepach, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) 
Director  Safdar Parvez, Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination 
Division, CWRD 
  Yong Ye, Urban Development and Water Division, CWRD 
   
Team leaders  Carmen M. Garcia Perez, Regional Cooperation Specialist, CWRD 
  Ramola Naik Singru, Senior Urban Development Specialist, CWRD 
Team members  Mark R. Bezuijen, Senior Environment Specialist, East Asia 
Department (EARD) 
  Zulfia K. Karimova, Principal Institutional Coordination Specialist, 
EARD 
  Xijie Lu, Young Professional, CWRD 
  Charles Felix S. Simbillo, Operations Analyst, CWRD 
  Gina S. Sinang, Senior Operations Assistant, CWRD 
  Ruby Y. Torralba, Senior Programs Assistant, CWRD 
  Guoliang Wu, Senior Regional Cooperation Specialist, CWRD

of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 03072019110526633027 Generated Date: 03-Jul-2019 11:07:07 AM  Page 2 of 2

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  regional  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  support  the 
development of a comprehensive framework to promote tourism development and cooperation in 
the  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC)  region,  including  through  the 
formulation of a CAREC tourism strategy leading to 2030 and a regional investment framework 
with projects to be implemented from 2021 to 2025. The TA will also seek to enhance the capacity 
of government agencies to collect and analyze tourism statistics, undertake market research, and 
promote dialogue and information-sharing between public and private tourism stakeholders in the 
region. 
 
2.  The TA supports the implementation of the CAREC 2030 strategy, as tourism is one of its 
operational priorities under cluster 2 (trade, tourism, and economic corridor development).1 The 
TA follows a comprehensive approach as it builds on and continues the work completed under 
TA for Enhancing Coordination of the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program and 
Implementing the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 2030 Strategy for Sustainable 
Regional Development.2 These TA projects have supported the initiation of the work of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) in the tourism sector in the CAREC region through the development of 
a scoping study on promoting regional tourism cooperation under CAREC 2030, and the conduct 
of the first regional tourism workshop under the CAREC Program in 2018.3 The TA aligns well 
with ADB Strategy 2030 as it supports two of its operational priorities—operational priority 7 on 
fostering regional cooperation and integration, and operational priority 4 on making cities more 
livable—as well as the promotion of technological development and digital transformation in 
several ADB developing member countries.4 The TA is also aligned with the Operational Plan for 
Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2016–2020.5 Tourism development is included in the 
national  strategies  of  CAREC  countries  as  a  means  to  achieve  sustainable  and  inclusive 
economic growth.6 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Since  its  inception  in  2001,  the  CAREC  Program  has  strongly  supported  regional 
connectivity  and  economic  corridor  development.7  As  CAREC  countries  become  more 
interconnected, they also need to work together to maximize the economic opportunities resulting 
from greater transport connectivity. Tourism can create and deepen socioeconomic and cultural 
ties across countries, improve connectivity, and foster better dialogue by bringing people and 
nations  closer  together.  Tourism  development  can  be  instrumental  in  promoting  economic 
diversification and job creation, and can help improve the economic viability of undertaking 
regional connectivity and economic corridor investments. It can also promote gender equality 
through job and income-generation opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises and 
entrepreneurs, including women and other vulnerable groups. 
 
                                                
1  CAREC Secretariat. 2017. CAREC 2030: Connecting the Region for Shared and Sustainable Development. Manila. 
2  ADB. Enhancing Coordination of the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program. and ADB. Implementing 
the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 2030 Strategy for Sustainable Regional Development.  
3  ADB. 2019. Promoting Regional Tourism Cooperation under CAREC 2030: A Scoping Study. Manila. 
4  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
5  ADB. 2016. Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2016–2020: Promoting Connectivity, 
Competitiveness, Regional Public Goods, and Collective Action for Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
6  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 28 May 2019. 
7  The CAREC Program is a partnership of 11 member countries (Afghanistan, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, 
Kyrgyz Republic, Mongolia, Pakistan, the People’s Republic of China, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan) and 
development partners, working to promote development through cooperation, leading to accelerated economic 
growth and shared prosperity.

2 
4.  Since 2010, tourism has experienced continued growth. In 2018, the tourism sector 
accounted for 10.4% of global gross domestic product and supported 319 million jobs, or 1 in 10 
jobs globally. International tourist arrivals reached 1.4 billion in 2018, a 6% increase from 2017. 
Asia and the Pacific was the second most visited region after Europe, with 343 million international 
arrivals. However, many CAREC countries lag behind other Asian economies when it comes to 
tourism development. In 2018, the aggregate volume of tourist arrivals amounted to almost 20 
million  and  the  tourism  sector  supported  6.3 million  jobs  in  the  CAREC  region (excluding 
Afghanistan, the People’s Republic of China and Turkmenistan).8 Taken in a global context, 
however, these figures represent less than 2% of global tourist arrivals and total employment in 
the tourism sector. In 2018, tourism’s direct contribution to CAREC member countries’ gross 
domestic product ranged from 10.1% (in Georgia) to 1.1% (in Uzbekistan). 
 
5.  Individually and collectively the CAREC countries have a wide range of natural and cultural 
resources to attract many segments of the international and domestic tourism markets. Many 
CAREC countries are making significant progress in developing and implementing national 
tourism strategies and policies, including in the area of visa liberalization. E-visa systems are now 
operational in seven CAREC countries;9 Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan have granted visa-free 
access to 45 countries starting from January 2017 and February 2019 respectively, and Pakistan 
has launched a new e-visa scheme for 175 countries in March 2019. The Silk Road visa, a joint 
initiative between Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan, is also underway. However, several factors still 
hinder tourism development in the region. 
 
(i)  Access to CAREC countries is still complex and time consuming because of limited air and 
land connectivity and cumbersome border control arrangements.10 
(ii)  Tourism infrastructure and services are of inconsistent quality and do not follow international 
standards. Intercity and public transport services are not regular, reliable, and inclusive; 
visitor information centers and effective signage on tourist routes are lacking; and access to 
basic utility services—such as water supply and sanitation, waste management, and heating 
and cooling—is limited, particularly in rural areas. In many CAREC countries, the regulatory 
framework for attracting tourism investments is also challenging. 
(iii)  Tourism planning, management, and promotion is ineffective because of (a) lack of national 
and regional coordination and dialogue between government agencies and private sector 
operators, (b) shortage of skilled hospitality workers and destination managers, and (c) low 
capacity of tourism agencies to collect and analyze data and undertake market research. 
Local  communities  have  little  involvement  in  tourism  planning  and  development, 
endangering preservation of the region’s cultural and environmental heritage. Insufficient 
knowledge of the CAREC region’s tourist assets among international consumers hampers 
efforts in regional tourism promotion and branding. 
 
6.  These barriers result in low volume of tourism flows and a weak image of the CAREC 
region as a competitive tourism destination globally. Opportunities exist to overcome these 
shortcomings  through  collaboration  among  CAREC  countries.  The  CAREC  2030  strategy 
advocates a regional approach to tourism development to help realize economies of scale from 
greater specialization and more efficient use of resources. Tourists often do not recognize national 
boundaries  and  typically  combine  two  or  more  neighboring  countries  when  selecting  their 
destinations.  Facilitating  travel  between  their  chosen  destination  countries  and  promoting 
multicountry experiences can increase socioeconomic benefits for each country in the region. 
 
                                                
8  World Travel and Tourism Council Data Gateway and UNWTO 2019. World Tourism Barometer. Volume 17, Issue 
1. Madrid. In the People’s Republic of China, tourist arrivals reached 63.5 million and the sector supported 82.4 
million jobs in 2018. 
9  Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Pakistan, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan. 
10 Visa requirements and cost, passport control systems, and time for clearance.

3 
7.  A scoping study conducted in 2018 identified the following potential areas for collaborative 
tourism  actions  (footnote  3):  (i)  simplification  of  visa  and  entry  procedures,  infrastructure 
development  on  cross-border  routes,  and  improvement  of  air  transport  connectivity;11  (ii) 
development  of  common  standards  and  certification  schemes  for  tourist  facilities;  (iii) 
development of tourism education and training courses with common curricula and qualifications; 
(iv) joint marketing and promotion activities under the Silk Road umbrella in collaboration with the 
World Tourism Organization Silk Road Programme; and (v) promotion of regulatory reforms and 
creation of an enabling environment for tourism investments. The findings of the scoping study 
were  discussed  at  the  first  CAREC  regional  tourism  consultation  workshop  in  Tashkent, 
Uzbekistan, on 23–24 October 2018. During the workshop, tourism officials and private sector 
representatives from the 11 CAREC countries emphasized the importance of establishing and 
maintaining regular dialogue to advance tourism cooperation under CAREC. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: sustainable and more inclusive tourism 
development in the CAREC region (footnote 1). The TA will have the following outcome: increased 
cooperation among CAREC countries to position the region as a globally attractive tourism 
destination.12 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: CAREC tourism sector strategy 2030 developed. The TA will support the 
development of a tourism strategy, which will set out a vision and a road map toward 2030, in 
alignment  with  all  member  countries’  tourism  priorities.  It  will  build  on  the  findings  and 
recommendations of the tourism scoping study as well as past and ongoing trade and economic 
corridor work in several CAREC countries,13 and other development partners’ tourism initiatives.14 
The strategy will adopt a holistic approach by covering several areas: (i) travel facilitation and 
connectivity; (ii) gender-inclusive human resources and skills development in hospitality; (iii) 
tourism infrastructure and services; (iv) tourism marketing and promotion; and (v) institutional 
arrangements for tourism, including clearly defined roles for the public and private sectors.15 The 
strategy will include a sound institutional coordination mechanism to effectively implement and 
monitor tourism-related initiatives under CAREC. The TA will conduct demand analyses and asset 
mapping per country to identify priority subregional groupings and thematic-based clusters, (e.g. 
heritage tourism, adventure tourism, ecotourism, Islamic tourism, and urban tourism); and assess 
infrastructure and urban services needs within the identified tourism clusters. The TA will consult 
and hold brainstorming sessions with regional, national, and provincial government agencies; the 
private sector; and local communities. 
                                                
11 ADB. 2018. Aviation and the Role of CAREC: A Scoping Study. Manila. The recommendations of this scoping study 
will be implemented to improve air transport connectivity. 
12 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
13 This includes the joint tourism mountain cluster initiative currently being developed under the Almaty–Bishkek 
Economic Corridor; the trilateral economic corridor initiative among Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, and Tajikistan; planned 
tourism-related interventions under the CAREC Integrated Trade Agenda 2030; and ongoing and planned ADB 
tourism projects in Georgia, Mongolia, and Tajikistan. 
14 This includes the European Union’s Silk Roads Heritage Corridors project being implemented by the United Nations 
Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO). 
15 Cross-cutting themes will be mainstreamed across all strategy components, such as (i) gender equality, including 
improving the readiness of women to access the benefits of tourism in the region; (ii) environmental and social 
sustainability, including assessing potential negative impacts resulting from “overtourism” and proposed mitigation 
measures; and (iii) the use of information and communication technologies. A gender-inclusive strategy will take into 
account social and gender issues relevant to tourism and will focus on bringing benefits (in terms of jobs, livelihoods, 
and safety) to the region for women, men, persons with disabilities, and other vulnerable groups.

4 
 
10.  Output  2:  Regional  tourism  investment  framework  for  2021–2025  prepared.  A 
regional investment framework will complement the CAREC tourism sector strategy, with specific 
projects to be implemented from 2021 to 2025 in all CAREC countries. It will comprise hard and 
soft infrastructure interventions in the areas covered by the strategy. Project profiles will be 
developed, including rationale; scope of the project; implementation period; indicative budget; and 
potential financing options, including public–private partnerships. Special attention will be given 
to secondary cities along multicountry tourism circuits, economic corridors, high-demand tourism 
areas identified by the demand analyses, and gender-inclusive interventions. 
 
11.  Output 3: Institutional capacity of tourism authorities and exchange of information 
enhanced. The TA will support conducting workshops and training activities to enhance the 
capacity of governments for tourism planning and policy making, including improving their ability 
to collect and analyze tourism statistics, undertake market research, and enhance tourism 
branding and promotion. It will promote knowledge and experience sharing through twinning 
arrangements, peer-to-peer learning events, study tours, and forums to foster public–private 
dialogue. The TA will also develop a CAREC tourism virtual portal linked to the CAREC website 
to consolidate and disseminate tourism-related information, and will identify sustainable options 
for maintaining and updating the web portal beyond the TA implementation period.16 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $2.0 million, of which (i) $0.5 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6), and (ii) $1.5 million will be financed 
on a grant basis by the United Kingdom Fund for Asia Regional Trade and Connectivity under the 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility and administered by ADB.17 
The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TA. The Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination 
Division and the Urban Development and Water Division of the Central and West Asia Department 
will jointly implement the TA. They will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; organize 
consultation workshops and seminars; and monitor TA implementation in close coordination with 
the East Asia Department, resident missions, and other relevant operations and knowledge 
departments. The TA will be implemented from July 2019 to December 2021. 
 
14.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions. ADB will recruit a consulting firm using the fixed budget selection method for 
the formulation of the CAREC tourism strategy 2030; the preparation of the regional investment 
framework 2021–2025; and the development of a CAREC tourism portal. In addition, ADB will 
engage up to 6 person-months of international and up to 10 person-months of national consultant 
inputs for capacity building and training events, and outreach activities. ADB will monitor and 
                                                
16 The tourism portal will provide a single entry point to tourism-related information and services for tourists interested 
in visiting several CAREC countries. The specific content and services provided through this platform will be decided 
in close consultation with public and private stakeholders in CAREC countries. 
17 The TA will contribute to climate change adaptation and mitigation targets through project concepts with high climate 
change impact (e.g., ecotourism projects); and inclusion of environmental sustainability as a key cross-cutting theme 
of the strategy, including measures to mitigate potential negative environmental impacts from over-tourism. Hence, 
the indicative contribution to adaptation and mitigation targets ($0.65 million) is equivalent to the cost estimated for 
output 2 (project concepts produced under the regional investment framework).

5 
evaluate the TA based on the implementation of activities and satisfactory delivery of outputs 
following the agreed time line and budget.18 
 
15.  Cofinancier requirements. Semiannual progress reports will be provided to the United 
Kingdom Fund for Asia Regional Trade and Connectivity under the Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Financing Partnership Facility, including an overview of expenditures. 
 
16.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $1,500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the United Kingdom Fund for Asia 
Regional Trade and Connectivity under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing 
Partnership Facility and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 
on a grant basis for Sustainable Tourism Development in the Central Asia Regional Economic 
Cooperation Region, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                
18 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Appendix 1  7 
Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  CAREC tourism strategy 2030 developed 
1.1 Prepare asset mapping and tourism demand analyses per country (Q3 2019–Q1 2020) 
1.2 Assess infrastructure and urban services needs in priority tourism clusters (Q4 2019–Q1 2020) 
1.3 Review the institutional structures for tourism development in CAREC countries and analyze best 
practices from other countries and regions, at national and regional levels (Q3–Q4 2019) 
1.4 Prepare a supply–demand analysis of hospitality skills in CAREC countries, taking gender aspects 
into consideration (Q3 2019–Q1 2020) 
1.5 Take stock of past and ongoing initiatives in the tourism and hospitality sector from other 
development partners (Q3 2019–Q4 2019) 
1.6 Define the scope of work of the envisaged tourism expert group and convene meetings, consultation 
workshops, and brainstorming sessions to gather countries’ and development partners’ inputs on the 
various topical analyses and the overall CAREC tourism strategy (Q3 2019–Q4 2020) 
1.7 Prepare the overall CAREC tourism strategy 2030 based on the inputs from the topical analyses and 
consultations (Q1 2020–Q4 2020) 
1.8 Disseminate the CAREC tourism strategy 2030 (Q1 2021–Q4 2021) 
 
2.  Regional investment framework for 2021–2025 prepared 
2.1 Conduct consultation workshops with CAREC member countries to identify priority tourism projects 
for hard and soft infrastructure interventions (Q1 2020–Q2 2020) 
2.2 Prepare the regional investment framework, 2021–2025 to complement the CAREC tourism strategy 
(Q3 2020–Q4 2020) 
2.3 Prepare no less than four project profiles, including project description, implementation period, and 
indicative budget and financing options (Q3 2020–Q2 2021) 
 
3.  Institutional capacity of tourism authorities and exchange of information enhanced 
3.1 Conduct seminars and training programs to enhance the capacity of tourism-related agencies in 
tourism planning and management, and data collection and analysis, including developing and 
improving systems of tourism statistics and tourism satellite accounts in CAREC countries (Q3 2019–
Q3 2021) 
3.2 Facilitate public–private dialogue and exchange of experiences and best practices among policy 
makers, private sector operators, small and medium-sized enterprises, female entrepreneurs, and 
youth, and other vulnerable groups through the organization of forums, conferences, and study tours 
(Q3 2019–Q3 2021) 
3.3 Collect and consolidate countries’ tourism-related information in a virtual portal (Q3 2019–Q3 2020) 
3.4 Update information on the virtual portal as necessary (Q3 2020–Q4 2021) 
3.5 Identify options and develop a comprehensive plan for maintaining and updating the virtual portal 
beyond the TA implementation period (Q3 2020–Q4 2021) 
Inputs 
ADB: $0.5 million (TASF 6) 
ARTCF: $1.5 million

Not Applicable

Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility, CAREC = Central Asia Regional Economic 
Cooperation, TA = technical assistance. 
Note: The TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000, of which contributions from ADB and the United Kingdom Fund for Asia 
Regional Trade and Connectivity under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility are 
presented in the table. ARTCF cofinancing will be used on a front-loaded basis.  
a  Financed by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). 
b  Administered by ADB. 
c  Includes surveys, reports, and translation into the Russian language. 
d  Publications will be printed for consultation meetings and workshops, as well as for major CAREC events and high-
level policy forums, including the CAREC ministerial conference, the senior officials’ meeting, and the national focal 
points’ meeting. 
e  These include training, study tours, peer-to-peer learning events, and forums and conferences to promote public–
private dialogue among tourism-related stakeholders. 
f  Facilitators may be engaged as resource persons. 
Source: ADB estimates.

Appendix 3  9
